details.title: Reliability Analysis of Hierarchical Systems Using Statistical Moments

p: Gerard Reijns received a MSc. in Electrical Engineering from Delft University of Technology. He worked at the PTT laboratory, an air defense lab, and at the European Space Agency in the period 1956-1972. He joined, as an Associate Professor, Delft University of Technology in 1972, and became Full Professor in 1980. At present he is an emeritus professor, but still active two days per week at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics, and Computer Science; and at the Faculty of Aerospace Engineering. His fields of special interest are computer performance, parallel processing, and image archiving and communication systems for hospitals. He was consultant to the Netherlands Aerospace Agency from 1971 to 1995, and chairman of Technical Committee 10 of the International Federation for Information processing from 1987 to 1993. He is author of more than 100 articles, and co-editor of several books.

Arjan J. C. van Gemund received a BS degree in Physics in 1981, an MS degree cum laude in Computer Science in 1989, and a PhD degree cum laude in 1996, all from Delft University of Technology. Between 1981 and 1985, he worked as an Electrical Engineer, and Systems Programmer at the R & D organization of a Dutch multinational company. Between 1989 and 1992, he joined the Dutch TNO research organization as a Research Scientist specialized in the field of high-performance computing. Since 1992, he is a faculty member at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics, and Computer Science of Delft University of Technology, currently serving as a Full Professor. His research interests are in the area of systems fault diagnosis, systems dependability, and parallel and distributed systems programming. He (co)authored more than 100 scientific papers.

details.abstract: In many practical engineering circumstances, systems reliability analysis is complicated by the fact that the failure time distributions of the constituent subsystems cannot be accurately modeled by standard distributions. In this paper, we present a low-cost, compositional approach based on the use of the first four statistical moments to characterize the failure time distributions of the constituent components, subsystems, and top-level system. The approach is based on the use of Pearson distributions as an intermediate analytical vehicle, in terms of which the constituent failure time distributions are approximated. The analysis technique is presented for -out-of- systems with identical subsystems, series systems with different subsystems, and systems exploiting standby redundancy. The moment-in-moment-out approach allows for the analysis of systems with arbitrary hierarchy, and arbitrary (unimodal) failure time distributions, provided the subsystems are independent such that the resulting failure time can be expressed in terms of sums or order statistics. The technique consistently exhibits very good accuracy (on average, much less than 1 percent error) at very modest computing cost.

links.abstract: In the study of the reliability of technical systems, k-out-of-n systems play an important role. In the present paper, we consider a k-out-of-n system consisting of n identical components with independent lifetimes having a common distribution function F. Under the condition that, at time t, all the components of the system are working, we propose a new definition for the mean residual life (MRL) function of the system, and obtain several properties of that system.

references.title:
Predicting execution times of parallel-independent
programs using Pearson distributions

context.text: An application of the Pearson distribution has been presented in [15] for the execution time analysis of parallel task compositions, where a very good accuracy was demonstrated (generally better than 1 percent for various distributions, including negative exponential, Gaussian, and uniform distributions).
Specific issues arising in the numerical implementation are detailed in [15].

In the following, we present the derivation of \$g(x)\$ when the roots of (11) are real, and have different signs (coined Pearson pdf of type I [3], the other two cases, and associated Pearson types II & III are detailed in [15]).

The Pearson approximation of the exact Gaussian distribution does not work correctly, as its representation by point \$B_{1}=0\$, \$B_{2}=3\$ in Table 1 of [15] lies on the border of the region type II.
The negative exponential pdf lies on the border of Pearson type III, and is represented by point \$B_{1}=4\$, \$B_{2}=9\$ in Table 1 of [15].

Following Section III-B, we mainly present implementation details for Pearson type I pdf only, as the implementation details for the other Pearson types are similar, except for the expressions for \$g_{i}(x)\$, and their domains [15].
The algorithm also applies to the other Pearson pdf types, in which case the computations in algorithm lines 1, 5, and 10, and the integration bounds on \$x\$ are altered accordingly [15].
While in [15] we have provided ample proof of the basic accuracy of our method, in the following we also provide error values, which also show the high accuracy for hierarchical composition.

references.text: G. L. Reijns, A. J. C. van Gemund, "Predicting execution times of parallel-independent programs using Pearson distributions", Parallel Computing, vol. 31, pp. 877-899, 2005.
